title: Conceptual Art

hook.text: Sol LeWitt: 'The idea becomes the machine that makes the art.' Conceptual Art declared that the concept behind the work is more important than the physical object. You don't need to make anything â€” thinking IS making.

buildup.text: Conceptual Art (1960s-present): Joseph Kosuth (a chair, a photo of the chair, and the dictionary definition of 'chair'), Yoko Ono (instruction pieces), On Kawara (daily date paintings). Art as philosophy.

discovery.text: The question shifted: not 'Is this beautiful?' but 'Is this art?' â€” and more importantly, 'What IS art?' Conceptual Art made the definition of art itself the artwork's subject.

twist.text: Marcel Duchamp did it first with his urinal ('Fountain,' 1917): an ordinary object declared art by the artist's decision. If anything can be art because the artist says so, then the idea â€” not the object â€” is what matters.

climax.text: Today, much contemporary art is conceptual: installations, performances, interventions, relational aesthetics. The question 'But is it art?' is itself the proof that Conceptual Art succeeded â€” it made us question everything.

punchline.text: Conceptual Art freed art from objects. The thought counts.

quiz.question: What does Conceptual Art prioritize?
options: The idea or concept behind the work over the physical object
